I think Test=
NG's scope is broader than that.

My understanding of "unit testing" is tha=
t it is supposed to exercise one

, public and private methods, make

level.

Anything including logic that =
involves more than one class is no longer
considered unit testing.  It can =
be called integration, acceptance,
functional, etc...  but it's no longer u=
nit testing.

Real code relies on dependencies all the time:

- A certain o=
bject can only be created if a previous object has been created
before.
- T=
his method can only be invoked if such field has been initialized.
- etc...=


It makes a lot of sense to me that my tests should reflect this complexit=
y
so they can run my real code.

I am a firm believer that tests should be =
as close as possible to production
code.  I don't know about you, but:

- I=
 am nervous when I run my tests on Postgresql and the production site
runs =
on Oracle.

- I feel ever worse when my tests are using mocks, because not =
only are
mocks non trivial to write (and they require you to maintain a par=
allel line
of code), they can give you a deadly sense of security.  And the=
n one day,
your mock tests run fine but the production code breaks, and you=
 enter a
world of pain.  Trust me, it's not pretty.

With all that in mind,=
 it makes sense to have a testing framework that takes
dependencies into ac=
count and makes it as easy as possible for you to:

- Identify which test *=
really* broke (compare "1 SUCESS 25 FAILED" to "1
SUCCESS 1 FAILED and 23 S=
KIPS").
- Allow you to rerun the failed tests easily, including all the dep=
endencies
